1.  Will the Catalan government be able to declare a result?

I have this at p= 0.40 today (up from 0.20 previously).   I think people will turn out.  I think the police forces will fail to prevent people turning out lodging ballots.  I think there'll be plenty of social media posts of people voting "Leave". However, despite the zeitgeist, newspaper stories, and Catalan Government cheerleading, I have major doubts about the processes that will be rolled out tomorrow.  I have doubts that ballot boxes and papers will be available at all, or even most, polling stations.  I have major doubts about whether electoral officials will turn up on the day.   I think there is a good chance we will see polling stations with thousands of people queuing ... and only a single official with a single ballot box and a few hundred papers ... and perhaps no electoral roll.  The police won't even have to make an arrest.  They'll just take the official's name and say, "Go home now, or we will fine you thousands of euro next week".  There may be insufficient officials to maintain ballot box security, or make a valid count at the end of the day.  (Running elections is hard work, and that is in the best of circumstances.) So I think it is still somewhat less that 50% likely that, within the next few days, the Catalan Government will wind up with any sort of reliable count on it's desk of i) total number of votes cast and counted and ii) how those votes were cast.  (Or rather, a reliable count that is large enough to warrant a result.  It is possible they might have a "reliable count" for a couple of percent of the electorate, and a "guess count" for many more.) WILL THEY?
So let's assume the Catalan Government, by Wednesday morning, has a (reasonably) reliable result showing a 20% turnout and a result 95% in favour of independence.  Would they declare that as an official result? I have this at p= 0.60 today (up from 0.50 previously). Regardless of the results in front of them, the vote will be clearly compromised.  There will be numerous reports of people wanting to vote, but being unable to.  There will quickly be reports of numerous "irregularities" in balloting procedures, and substandard scrutiny of the count.  (See the newspaper reports about irregularities in how the electoral officials have been contacted.)  International observers will, in some small degree, be present.  The Catalan Government thinks this is good: it will show "oppression" by Spanish forces.  More likely those observers will say: "This vote was a complete shambles." It is a near certainty that _no-one_ will honestly believe that the results are truly indicative of the public will. So does the Catalan Government declare that result?  I have discussed the possible motivations for the Catalan government here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/583622 (see about half-way down).  I am not sure whether the pro-independence cause is better served in a hearts-and-minds sense by claiming:
i)  "We cannot declare a result!  Our vote was robbed!  The will of the people was thwarted!  The Spanish are fascists!"; or
ii)  "We won!  We declare unilateral independence!" ... and trying to trigger a Spanish military response. Trouble is that the Catalan Government has been giving _seriously_ mixed messages on whether there will be unilateral declaration of independence ("DUI" in Catalan) after a "Leave" vote.  If there is no intent to have a DUI, then there is _no_ reason to declare an official win for the "Leave" vote.  On the other hand, there is certainly a sense of momentum within the Catalan leadership bunker, and they may well have personal motivations to declare a win for "Leave".  So I think it is a little more likely than not that, if the Catalan Government can declare a win for "Leave", that they will. As an aside, if we get the low-probability outcome of the "Remain" vote getting a majority, I think it is a certainty that the Catalan Government would declare: "The vote was disrupted; we can't declare a result."  So it is now p<0.005 that a vote will be held and "Remain" will win (ie. 0% with rounding).

In June 2017 a referendum on Catalan independence was announced by the Government of Catalonia for 1 October 2017. The Catalan government’s decree officially calling the referendum is expected to be approved in the second half of August. The Government of Spain opposes any Catalan self-determination referendum, maintaining that the Spanish Constitution does not allow for a vote on the independence of any Spanish region while also deeming it as illegal without its consent; an interpretation also favoured by the not binding Catalan Statutory Guarantees Council.
In the absence of constitutional grounds, the Catalan government invokes the right to self-determination for calling the referendum. However, the Council of Europe, when consulted by Carles Puigdemont, president of Catalan government, said that any referendum must be carried out “in full compliance with the constitution”. So far, the Catalan government has tried but failed to get international support; in particular, Spain’s European partners see Catalonia’s status as a strictly internal matter. Background
The ballot was initially scheduled for no later than 17 September 2017, a result of an election pledge made by pro-independence parties ahead of the 2015 Catalan election (during the previous legislature, the Catalan government had held a non-binding "citizen participation process" about the question).
The election resulted in a minority government for the Together for Yescoalition (JxSí), which had won a plurality of MPs (62 of the 135 seats), plus conditional support from the 10 CUP-CC MPs. Shortly after the government was formed, it resolved to hold a referendum on independence. Shortly after the referendum was announced, attention focused on the issue of the ballot boxes, since the Government of Spain is in charge of providing them, whereas for this not State-sanctioned vote, the Generalitat would have to put them in place, potentially risking prosecution for misuse of public funds. On 24 March, the Spanish Public Prosecutor's Office in Catalonia had already announced an inquiry to determine whether a referendum is in the planning.
Tendering by the Catalan government for materials such as ballot papers and envelopes for a putative regional election in the region are thought by some to be an attempt to covertly organize the referendum.
In terms of its organization, besides the unconstitutionality of the poll, the electoral roll is one of the main points in contention, since this is managed by the National Institute of Statistics, an autonomous organization placed under the jurisdiction of the government of Spain. To have access to its data, polls must have been authorized by the Spanish Congress, something which is out of the question in this case.[23]Without an undisputed access to the electoral roll, the results can be deemed unreliable. Similar difficulties could be met when it comes to the electoral commission to be formed for monitoring the polling and results. An official announcement by the Generalitat suggested that Catalan residents overseas willing to vote would have to register. By the end of June 2017, out of 285,000 Catalans living abroad and eligible to vote, 5,000 had registered. Tensions within the Catalan government
On July 3, president Puigdemont sacked his Minister for Enterprise, Jordi Baiget, who, in the face of the legal challenges, had just expressed doubts regarding the referendum taking place as envisioned by the Catalan government. Then, on July 14, Puigdemont proceeded with a cabinet reshuffle, replacing three additional ministers in his cabinet (the ones responsible for Presidency, Education and Interior) in a move widely seen as a removal of the remainder hesitant voices within his cabinet in regards to the referendum issue. On July 17, the Catalan police chief resigned without giving any reason. The regional police force is seen as key to enforcing any court orders sought by the Spanish government challenging the secession vote. Additional isolated resignations have been noted among some of the high-level civil servants potentially playing a role with the vote's organization. Economic repercussions
As of August 2017 the spread between Spanish 10-year government debt and German bonds was close to its narrowest in seven years; however, since the start of July the yield on the Catalan government’s bonds had jumped by about 50 basis points, signaling unease among investors in regards to the referendum. Pollsters generally started using the proposed referendum question ("Do you want Catalonia to be an independent state in the form of a republic?") after it was revealed in early June 2017. The Opinion Studies Center (CEO) polled respondents on their intentions rather than asking them the actual referendum question. In its March 2017 poll, aside from asking respondents whether they would want Catalonia to become an independent state, it asked their intents in the event of a referendum on the independence of Catalonia being called and organized by the Generalitat without agreement from the Spanish Government.
